column1: 75|Graduate Research Student Assistant|"Graduate Research Student Assistant
Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation – University of Washington
Location: 2301 5th Ave
Position Title: Graduate Research Student Assistant
Start Date: 7/23/2018
End Date: 9/25/2018
This position is 40 hours per week.
Position Description

IHME has an outstanding opportunity for a Graduate Research Assistant to join the Cost Effectiveness team. The Graduate Research Assistant will have the opportunity to learn about data analysis and cost effectiveness in the context of global disease burden
column4: and interventions. IHME’s Cost Effectiveness team is currently developing a machine-learning approach to analyze all available data on cost-effectiveness analyses (CEAs) using the Tufts Medical Center CEA registries. The registries serve as a repository of cost effectiveness data from the literature that uses two metrics to assess the impact of a specific health intervention in a country or region: cost per quality-adjusted life year (QALY) gained
column5: and cost per disability-adjusted life year (DALY) averted. Our goal is to meta-regress all of the available cost per QALY and cost per DALY data to predict a full range of cost effectiveness ratios for each country and health intervention. For additional information in the registries
column6: see Neumann et al. Comparing the cost-per-QALYs gained and cost-per-DALYs averted literatures. Gates Open Research. 2018.

column1: For this project
column2: the Graduate Research Assistant will assist in the preparation of data for statistical modeling. Specific duties will involve researching existing health intervention taxonomies
column3: evaluating them against the project’s needs
column4: and coding registry entries using the selected taxonomy. If existing taxonomies show little promise for the registry data
column5: the Graduate Research Assistant will have the opportunity to develop a custom system for classifying and structuring the data
column6: as well as to test and document the taxonomy and present findings to all project collaborators. The Graduate Research Assistant’s contribution will impact future global health research on cost effectiveness
column7: by illuminating which health interventions should be of highest priority in addressing global disease burden moving forward.

column1: Duties include:
Research existing health intervention taxonomies and apply results to the standardization and classification of Tufts Medical Center registry data
Code registry entries using the selected taxonomy
Extract additional information from articles in registry to code entries consistently and accurately
Perform quality assurance on coding and data
Develop documentation to share methods and results with collaborators at IHME
Present project findings to IHME Cost Effectiveness team
Participate in other research activities as needed by the project
Minimum Requirements
Currently enrolled graduate student at the University of Washington during AY 18/19
Strong quantitative aptitude
column3: and ability to interpret complex analytic information

column1: Strong sense of focus and attention to detail
Ability to learn new information quickly and to apply analytic skills to describe complex information in a systematic way
Interest in global health
Demonstrated organizational skills
Self-motivated and able to work well in a collaborative
Desired qualification
Enrolled in graduate program in library and information science
Successfully completed UW course LIS 537 Construction of Indexing Languages
Experience working with databases
Coding experience

This position is open to currently enrolled graduate students at the University of Washington during AY 18/19. This position may be eligible for benefits. Questions regarding salary and benefits should be directed to IHME Human Resources at ihmehr@uw.edu.

column2: Sanitation Industry & Technology Transition Liaison|"The Global Growth & Opportunity (GGO) division works to catalyze sustainable transformative change in the face of inequities and market failures
column3: to realize the potential of untapped markets
column4: and to see the economic and social benefits of including everyone. We focus on the areas of Agricultural Development; Financial Services for the Poor; Water
column5: Sanitation and Hygiene; and Gender Equality. We seek solutions that are sustainable
column7: and inclusive with an eye toward applying technology innovations as well as data evidence to drive change in the world’s developing countries.

column1: 4.5 billion people worldwide lack access to safely managed sanitation
column2: and millions of these people live in dwellings whose sanitary facilities
column4: are connected to poorly managed septic tanks
column5: cesspools or latrines. Health impacts of poorly managed sanitation are severe
column6: including hundreds of millions of cases of serious oral-fecal illnesses each year
column7: resulting in the preventable deaths of approximately 1.7 million young children
column8: and lifelong stunting and cognitive impairment of tens of millions more children

column1: Traditional sewer networks have historically been the preferred sanitation solution among urban planners and governments. However
column2: this large and centralized infrastructure is often not the most sustainable
column3: nor financially or technically feasible solution in developing countries
column4: and often does not reach informal settlement populations and other vulnerable groups for a range of reasons including sewers not extending beyond central business districts
column6: lack of legal recognition by government
column7: or project cost estimates that don’t include the costs to connect poor households to sewers.

column1: These factors make non-sewered sanitation solutions (NSS)
column2: also known as onsite sanitation systems
column3: more context-appropriate and adaptable in many urban contexts. The Water
column4: Sanitation & Hygiene (WSH) team focuses their efforts and resources towards advocating and developing an end-to-end ecosystem promoting NSS. This is achieved through:

column1: Policy
column3: and Communication (PAC) targets our focus regions to promote national policies and increase government accountability for responsible fecal sludge management (FSM). In addition
column4: focus is also placed on advocating for funding innovative non-sewered sanitation interventions globally.

column1: Transformative Technology Commercialization (TTC)supports upstream development of innovative technologies that practically address the sanitation challenge and respects the realities of developing world needs. Current focus has shifted towards bringing these technologies to market through diverse and locally relevant commercialization strategies.
Urban Sanitation Markets (USM) places emphasis on developing the market and ecosystem for city wide inclusive sanitation services
column3: and transformative technologies. This includes building the capacity of those responsible for sanitation services to develop appropriate business models and build effective NSS systems and infrastructure. This is achieved through collaboration with national governments

column1: Measurement
column3: and Dissemination for Scale (MEDS)is tasked with strengthening the evidence base for successful and innovative sanitation programs
column4: supporting smart measurement and indicators within our grant making
column5: and helping the NSS sector more broadly implement evidenced based programming through dissemination of findings.

column1: As mentioned above
column2: the Transformative Technology Commercialization (TTC) strategy leads the upstream development of innovative technologies and the WSH team has partnered with many universities and industries to develop these technologies as core processing systems or key components for the next generation of safe and sustainable sanitation solutions. These technologies will enable the development
column3: manufacturing and deployment of Reinvented Toilets (as defined by ISO30500)
column4: Omni-Ingestors (inline pit emptying and waste treatment solutions) and Omni-Processors (energy independent fecal sludge processing technologies
column5: as defined by ISO/IWA28); which aim to kill pathogens from human waste and waste streams and turn human waste into marketable products that support an entrepreneur’s business profitability. In addition to the upstream work
column6: the WSH team is also partnering with leading industry and commercial entities around the world to successfully deploy these technologies in communities in developing and developed countries where they will have the most health and economic benefits.

The Washington State Ferries has an outstanding opportunities for engineer technicians to serve as construction inspectors/material testers for Ferry Terminal construction projects. You will be responsible for collaborating in inspecting unique construction projects and assisting in creating solutions specific to WSF Ferry Terminal needs. It's a rare opportunity to truly make a mark in facilities that represent a true Washington State icon. Some who thrives in an atmosphere of substantial responsibility and finds fulfillment in such work is sure to succeed at our agency.

The ferry system is represented by a truly talented Engineering Team which supports the largest ferry system in the United States. The Attorney General's Office is recruiting for a permanent full time Legal Assistant 4 in the Transportation and Public Construction (TPC) Division. This position is located in Tumwater. Note: There is the possibility of an in-training from the Legal Assistant 3 level.
The TPC division represents the Washington State Department of Transportation (WSDOT)
column3: and many other transportation related state client agencies in state and federal courts throughout Washington. The workload is a mix of litigation and client advice as well as other general agency initiatives and assignments. Our division handles eminent domain actions
column7: regulatory compliance and defense of hazardous waste claims
column8: land use issues that arise in connection with state projects
column10: and public records. Division attorneys also handle a number of tort cases seeking recovery of property damage allegedly caused by floods and landslides. Client advice topics range from land use and environmental permitting issues
column12: and constitutional issues on the use of state gas tax revenue. TPC fosters a collegial atmosphere
column13: and provides internal and external training and mentoring for its personnel.

The salary listed above is for the Legal Assistant 4 level. Applicants qualifying at the Legal Assistant 3 level will start at a salary range 44 ($38
column3: 004 annually) and after successful completion of the in-training will move to the Legal Assistant 4 range.

column1: The School of Oceanography has an outstanding opportunity for a Research Scientist/Engineer-Senior . This position is integral to a project engaged in the deployment of approximately 120 profiling floats per year in the global ocean for the purpose of studying the ocean’s role in the climate system. The floats are fabricated at UW and deployed from a variety of platforms
column4: container vessels and aircraft. Each float returns in situ temperature and salinity data at regular intervals via satellite
column5: and the data are used in quantitative analyses of climate change.

column1: This position examines data from a large suite of profiling floats in the world ocean in order to assess the quality of the data. Quality is assessed by using computer programing and physical oceanography knowledge to examine data collected by the floats in comparison to archival data. Duties include:
Propose corrections to the float data based on the analysis and comparisons with archival data by applying knowledge of physical oceanography principles and knowledge of global water masses
Discuss the results of the analyses with other members of the profiling float community (both UW and non-UW members) and collaborate on quality data discussions
Participate on committees and governing bodies in order to have the proposed adjustments applied both locally and globally to the float date
Write C and Matlab-based software for carrying out float data analyses
Prepare scientific reports for publication in refereed journals based on the proposed corrections and on scientific analyses of the float data

Participate in the float fabrication process by applying derived corrections to pre-deployment calibrations of temperature and salinity on the floats and providing baseline data from future deployment locations for float ballasting during the construction/fabrication process
Attend national and international meetings related to these duties on a frequent basis and will make oral presentations regarding the scientific analysis and overall progress of the project.
As a UW employee
column2: you will enjoy generous benefits and work/life programs. For detailed information on Benefits for this position

column1: Required:

PhD in Oceanography or related sciences and minimum of 4 years experience including physical oceanography knowledge of global water masses; C and Matlab programming skills; analytical abilities to identify instrument errors in ocean data.
Equivalent education/experience will substitute for all minimum qualifications except where there are legal requirements such as license/certification/registration.
Desired:
Thorough knowledge of water masses of the world’s oceans including temperature
column3: and dissolved oxygen properties; knowledge and use of modern methods of data analysis; knowledge of inverse methods; extensive familiarity with C and Matlab programming; knowledge of CTD system hardware and software; ability to communicate with scientist
column4: engineers and technicians involved with float construction.

column1: The Department of Microbiology is one of the premier biological science departments in the country. The department has a national reputation for high quality teaching and an international reputation for excellence in research. Because of the revolution in biology that began in the 1970s
column2: rapid advances in microbiology and the development of biotechnology have increased our understanding of all living systems. This has in large part been determined by studies of microorganisms. The research programs of the faculty in the Department of Microbiology at the University of Washington reflect exciting areas of modern microbiology. Our faculty span a broad range of interests including microbial ecology
column5: and microbial pathogenesis in both animal and plant systems. The members of our department are largely concerned with understanding the mechanisms by which organisms interact with one another and with their environment at the cellular and molecular levels. Because of the strong interdisciplinary nature of these interests
column6: numerous collaborative efforts between our faculty and those in other science and medicine departments have developed.

column1: The Department of Microbiology currently has an outstanding opportunity for a Research Scientist/Engineer Assistant .

The primary job functions are to perform laboratory procedures toward goals of specific research projects. Perform research aimed at understanding the mechanisms and phenotypic traits of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and other bacterial pathogens using cultures from patients with Cystic Fibrosis.
Experimental techniques to be performed are primarily with small animal models of infection and will include:
•15% Processing samples from sputum.
•20% Basic molecular biology
•10% Molecular manipulation of bacteria including cloning
column3: and preparing samples for genomic sequencing.

column1: •5% Isolate and characterize bacteria and prepare DNA from clinical samples.

•20% Assist laboratory members with experiments.
•5% Prepare laboratory reagents.
•5% Restock laboratory supplies.
•5% Participate in laboratory meetings and establish ownership of research projects.
•5% Perform related duties as required.

column2: Microbiology or other pertinent science field.

As a UW employee
column2: you have a unique opportunity to change lives on our campuses

column1: UW faculty and staff also enjoy outstanding benefits

column1: The School of Oceanography has an outstanding opportunity for a Research Scientist/Engineer-Senior . This position is integral to a project engaged in the deployment of approximately 120 profiling floats per year in the global ocean for the purpose of studying the ocean’s role in the climate system. The floats are fabricated at UW and deployed from a variety of platforms
column4: container vessels and aircraft. Each float returns in situ temperature and salinity data at regular intervals via satellite
column5: and the data are used in quantitative analyses of climate change.

column1: This position examines data from a large suite of profiling floats in the world ocean in order to assess the quality of the data. Quality is assessed by using computer programing and physical oceanography knowledge to examine data collected by the floats in comparison to archival data. Duties include:
Propose corrections to the float data based on the analysis and comparisons with archival data by applying knowledge of physical oceanography principles and knowledge of global water masses
Discuss the results of the analyses with other members of the profiling float community (both UW and non-UW members) and collaborate on quality data discussions
Participate on committees and governing bodies in order to have the proposed adjustments applied both locally and globally to the float date
Write C and Matlab-based software for carrying out float data analyses
Prepare scientific reports for publication in refereed journals based on the proposed corrections and on scientific analyses of the float data

Participate in the float fabrication process by applying derived corrections to pre-deployment calibrations of temperature and salinity on the floats and providing baseline data from future deployment locations for float ballasting during the construction/fabrication process
Attend national and international meetings related to these duties on a frequent basis and will make oral presentations regarding the scientific analysis and overall progress of the project.
As a UW employee
column2: you will enjoy generous benefits and work/life programs. For detailed information on Benefits for this position

column1: Required:

PhD in Oceanography or related sciences and minimum of 4 years experience including physical oceanography knowledge of global water masses; C and Matlab programming skills; analytical abilities to identify instrument errors in ocean data.
Equivalent education/experience will substitute for all minimum qualifications except where there are legal requirements such as license/certification/registration.
Desired:
Thorough knowledge of water masses of the world’s oceans including temperature
column3: and dissolved oxygen properties; knowledge and use of modern methods of data analysis; knowledge of inverse methods; extensive familiarity with C and Matlab programming; knowledge of CTD system hardware and software; ability to communicate with scientist
column4: engineers and technicians involved with float construction.

column1: The Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington (APL-UW) is a national center for advanced science and engineering research and development and education. APL-UW was formed in 1943 for the U.S. Navy to bring university research resources to bear on urgent WWII defense problems. APL-UW has developed an international reputation for its broad based programs in science
column4: and deploying the advanced technology required to meet the research needs of numerous government and commercial sponsors. With modern facilities

column7: dynamic work environment with many opportunities.

column1: APL has an outstanding opportunity for a full time Mechanical Engineer.
The Mechanical Engineer in the Applied Physics Laboratory's Ocean Engineering Department will be responsible for the design
column2: construction and field deployment of specialized mechanical systems for oceanographic and acoustic instrumentation. Design tasks will be varied and may range from structural frames and pressure vessels to electronics chassis and hydraulic systems. Special emphasis will be placed on the design of mechanical and electromechanical systems for long term operation in the ocean. Duties will contribute to a strategically important
column4: and multi-million dollar projects sponsored by the National Science Foundation (NSF)
column8: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) as well as opportunities for collaboration with other internal UW departments and other applied research centers at other universities.

column1: Specific work will be completed in the following areas:
The incumbent will use SolidWorks CAD software to design oceanographic hardware
column2: including but not limited to deep ocean mooring design

column1: The incumbent will perform stress analysis of oceanographic hardware using both structural analysis software (ANSYS FEA) and empirical equations.

The incumbent will coordinate with Applied Physics Laboratory Ocean Engineering machine shop and Field Engineers during the fabrication process to ensure the finished product meets design specifications.
The incumbent will coordinate the assembly and testing of mechanical hardware with other engineers and technicians.
The incumbent will serve as the design and engineering expert for at-sea installation/deployment and recovery of the oceanographic equipment.

Master's Degree in Mechanical Engineering and at least eight years of experience; equivalent education/experience will substitute for all minimum qualifications except when there are legal requirements
Experience with mechanical and ocean engineering design
Experience using mechanical computer-aided design tools

column2: and as part of a research team
column3: interacting cooperatively with people from diverse backgrounds

column1: Able to acquire and maintain a Department of Defense (DoD) security clearance

Please note: candidates with advanced degrees and additional experience are strongly encouraged to apply as they will all be considered for this recruitment at a level commensurate with their education and experience.
DESIRED:
Heat Transfer Analysis
Fluid Mechanics
Proficient in the creation of mechanical drawings
Hydraulic Systems
Corrosion Control
Simulation of mechanical systems using computer tools
Scuba diving experience or certification
